data.title: Movie Review: The Wizard of Gore (1970)
data.meta_description: Ah, yes, back to the well with another Herschell Gordon Lewis “classic.” This movie stars Ray Sager as magician Montag the Magnificent, who performs acts of mutilation on volunteers who appear…
data.text:
Ah, yes, back to the well with another Herschell Gordon Lewis “classic.” This movie stars Ray Sager as magician Montag the Magnificent, who performs acts of mutilation on volunteers who appear unharmed, but drop dead later in the same ways that they were “killed” by him.

It’s actually a pretty fun premise. I’m not going to say Ray Sager does a great job or anything like that. Like anyone else in a H.G. Lewis movie, he can’t really act. But there’s something about him that really works for this role specifically. He tends to do a lot of dramatic monologues that are done in one or very few takes, and he brings an appropriate level of theatricality to the role.

The gore is pretty fun and quite revolting, as well. After all, that’s why we’re here, isn’t it? It’s not for the filmmaking or the acting.

There’s almost a meta quality to all of this, with him being a magician. When special effects master Tom Savini talks about gore, he talks about it as if he’s a magician. He will talk about setting up…
